nodes.documentation:
@title Arbitrator
 Arbitrator abstract contract.
 When developing arbitrator contracts we need to:
 -Define the functions for dispute creation (createDispute) and appeal (appeal). Don't forget to store the arbitrated contract and the disputeID (which should be unique, may nbDisputes).
 -Define the functions for cost display (arbitrationCost and appealCost).
 -Allow giving rulings. For this a function must call arbitrable.rule(disputeID, ruling).
nodes.name: Arbitrator
DisputeCreation

@dev To be emitted when a dispute can be appealed.
 @param _disputeID ID of the dispute.

nodes.documentation:
@title Arbitrator
 Arbitrator abstract contract.
 When developing arbitrator contracts we need to:
 -Define the functions for dispute creation (createDispute) and appeal (appeal). Don't forget to store the arbitrated contract and the disputeID (which should be unique, may nbDisputes).
 -Define the functions for cost display (arbitrationCost and appealCost).
 -Allow giving rulings. For this a function must call arbitrable.rule(disputeID, ruling).
nodes.name: Arbitrator
DisputeCreation

nodes.documentation:
@dev To be emitted when a dispute can be appealed.
 @param _disputeID ID of the dispute.
nodes.name: AppealPossible
AppealDecision
createDispute
arbitrationCost
appeal
appealCost
appealPeriod
disputeStatus
currentRuling

appeal(uint256,bytes).details: Appeal a ruling. Note that it has to be called before the arbitrator contract calls rule.

params._disputeID: ID of the dispute to be appealed.
params._extraData: Can be used to give extra info on the appeal.

appealCost(uint256,bytes).details: Compute the cost of appeal. It is recommended not to increase it often, as it can be higly time and gas consuming for the arbitrated contracts to cope with fee augmentation.

params._disputeID: ID of the dispute to be appealed.
params._extraData: Can be used to give additional info on the dispute to be created.

appealPeriod(uint256).details: Compute the start and end of the dispute's current or next appeal period, if possible. If not known or appeal is impossible: should return (0, 0).
appealPeriod(uint256).return: The start and end of the period.

arbitrationCost(bytes).details: Compute the cost of arbitration. It is recommended not to increase it often, as it can be highly time and gas consuming for the arbitrated contracts to cope with fee augmentation.

params._extraData: Can be used to give additional info on the dispute to be created.

createDispute(uint256,bytes).details: Create a dispute. Must be called by the arbitrable contract. Must be paid at least arbitrationCost(_extraData).

params._choices: Amount of choices the arbitrator can make in this dispute.
params._extraData: Can be used to give additional info on the dispute to be created.

createDispute(uint256,bytes).return: disputeID ID of the dispute created.

currentRuling(uint256).details: Return the current ruling of a dispute. This is useful for parties to know if they should appeal.
currentRuling(uint256).return: ruling The ruling which has been given or the one which will be given if there is no appeal.

disputeStatus(uint256).details: Return the status of a dispute.

params._disputeID: ID of the dispute to rule.

disputeStatus(uint256).return: status The status of the dispute.

devdoc.title: Arbitrator Arbitrator abstract contract. When developing arbitrator contracts we need to: -Define the functions for dispute creation (createDispute) and appeal (appeal). Don't forget to store the arbitrated contract and the disputeID (which should be unique, may nbDisputes). -Define the functions for cost display (arbitrationCost and appealCost). -Allow giving rulings. For this a function must call arbitrable.rule(disputeID, ruling).
